intro: Phaeanthus lanceolatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaf phaeanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and thrives in partial to full shade. It produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
